title: 109_hr3296
content: The Act titled "Prekindergarten-Oriented Professional Support Act of 2005" provides grants for hiring and training eligible prekindergarten teachers. The Act allows the Secretary of Education to make grants to States and local educational agencies to support hiring and training new prekindergarten teachers to increase their numbers and expand children's access to early education. Recipients must use the funds to pay salaries, benefits, and training costs of teachers at eligible prekindergarten providers. Eligible providers include State, local, or private non-profit or for-profit prekindergarten providers. The Act allows grants to support hiring and training new prekindergarten teachers at eligible providers meeting high-quality standards and serving low-income children. The Secretary will issue standards for determining high-quality providers within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will issue standards for high-quality prekindergarten providers, considering criteria like administration, support services, health, safety, nutrition, parental involvement, teacher training, teacher-to-student ratio, and curriculum. These standards will align with or add to existing standards under the Head Start Act. The Secretary will issue standards for high-quality prekindergarten providers under the Head Start Act. Applicants for a grant must designate a lead agency, coordinate activities with other programs, and provide matching funds. The grant program requires applicants to contribute non-Federal funds amounting to at least 25% of the program costs, which can be in cash or in-kind contributions. Federal funds or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in the contribution amount. The grant program mandates a 25% non-Federal contribution, which cannot include Federal funds. The Secretary can waive this requirement due to financial constraints. Funds must supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, and local funding for early childhood programs. To apply for a grant, a State or local educational agency must submit an application meeting specified criteria to the Secretary. In making grants under this section, the Secretary shall prioritize States and local educational agencies with the greatest need for expanded access to high-quality early childhood education. Recipients of grants must monitor and report progress achieved through the grant. The Secretary shall prioritize States and local educational agencies with the greatest need for expanded access to high-quality early childhood education when making grants under this section. Recipients of grants must submit an annual progress report to Congress. Grants may be provided to States and local educational agencies to enhance retention of prekindergarten teachers through a career ladder program. This ladder offers incentives for teachers to pursue further education and training without devaluing the experience of those without formal education. In this Act, key terms are defined such as "eligible prekindergarten teacher" as someone pursuing a Bachelor of Arts in early childhood development, "low-income child" as a child from a family below 200 percent of the poverty line, and "poverty line" as defined by the Office of Management and Budget. The term "prekindergarten" refers to a program for children aged 3 to 5 that focuses on pre-literacy, pre-numeracy, emotion regulation, and behavioral skills for school success. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010.
